caption.center: JERRY JO LUDLOW STONE, APPELLANT, v. STATE OF ALASKA, APPELLEE.

opinion.posture: Appeal from the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Seaborn J. Buckalew, J.
opinion.attorneys:
Ben Esch, Dickson, Evans, Esch Papas, Anchorage, for appellant.
John A. Scukanec, Asst. Dist. Atty., Joseph D. Balfe, Dist. Atty., Anchorage, Avum M. Gross, Atty. Gen., Juneau, for appellee.
opinion.panel: Before RABINOWITZ, C.J., and CONNOR, BOOCHEVER, BURKE and MATTHEWS, JJ.
opinion.opinion_text:
Upon appellant's plea of no contest to eleven counts of forgery,[fn1] the superior court imposed a sentence of four years on each count,[fn2] to run concurrently. Appellant was made eligible for parole at the discretion ofPage 73 the parole board.[fn3] In this appeal she challenges the court's sentence as excessive.[fn4]
Our review of the record fails to persuade us that the superior court was clearly mistaken in imposing the sanction that it did.[fn5] Accordingly, its sentence is affirmed. McClain v.State, 519 P.2d 811 (Alaska 1974).
AFFIRMED.
[fn1] AS 11.25.020.
[fn2] Appellant was punishable upon each count by "imprisonment . . . for not less than one year nor more than 20 years." Id.
[fn3] See AS 33.15.180.
[fn4] See AS 12.55.120(a); Rule 21, Alaska R.App.P.
[fn5] Stone was employed as a full charge bookkeeper, and by her forgeries she embezzled over $7,000 from her employer. The forgeries in the present case commenced while she was still on probation from a 1975 conviction on a plea of guilty to three counts of embezzlement. Those offenses also involved forgeries of an employer's checks. At that time over $78,000 of embezzled funds were traced to Stone's bank account.
